case_name: State of Bihar v. Bipat Gope

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 242 of 1960 filed by the State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 242 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated June 2, 1958 of Patna High Court in Cr. Misc. 124/58.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 2, 1958, of the Patna High Court in Cr. Misc. 124/58. P. Verma for the appellant.

facts.text: Proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution and s. 491 of CrPC for writ of habeas corpus regarding detention of Bipat Gope.

anchor.surface_text: and it arises out of proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution and s. 491 of the Criminal Procedure Code for a writ of habeas companypus in the matter of detention of one Bipat Gope.

facts.text: Bipat Gope is a resident of Patna district.

anchor.surface_text: The present respondent was the petitioner in the High Court. Bipat Gope, a resident of the district of Patna, was companyvicted under s 323 s. 324 read with s. 511

facts.text: Bipat Gope convicted under ss. 323, 324 read with s. 511 IPC and sentenced to six months rigorous imprisonment on November 29, 1957 by Patna High Court on appeal against acquittal under s. 417 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Bipat Gope, a resident of the district of Patna, was companyvicted under s 323 s. 324 read with s. 511 of the Indian, Penal Code and sentenced on November 29, 1957, to six months rigorous imprisonment by the High Court on appeal against acquittal under s. 417

facts.text: Bipat Gope not taken into custody until January 6, 1958, then kept under armed guard in Patna Medical College Hospital paying ward due to serious illness.

anchor.surface_text: but he was number taken into custody till January 6, 1958 and even then he was kept under armed guard in the Patna Medical College Hospital in one of the paying wards, on the ground that he was seriously ill.

facts.text: Bipat Gope released by District Magistrate on March 11, 1958 under Jail Manual rules when unexpired imprisonment was four months and three days.

anchor.surface_text: On an application by the respondent and on the recommendation of the appropriate medical authority Bipat Gope was released by the District Magistrate on March 11, 1958 under the rules of the Jail Manual when his unexpired period of imprisonment was four months and three days.

facts.text: State contends Bipat Gope released under R. 549 Jail Manual (conditional release).

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellant State is that he was released under R. 549 which is the rule providing for companyditional release of prisoners but the respondent challenges the factum of release under this Rule.

facts.text: Respondent challenges that Bipat Gope was released under R. 549.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellant State is that he was released under R. 549 which is the rule providing for companyditional release of prisoners but the respondent challenges the factum of release under this Rule.

facts.text: Sureties for Bipat Gope failed to produce him; notices issued April 27, 1958 to show cause why surety bonds forfeited; non-bailable warrant ordered.

anchor.surface_text: The sureties for Bipat Gope were called upon to produce him but as they had failed to do so numberices were issued to them by an order dated April 27, 1958, to show cause why their surety bonds should number be forfeited. By the same order numberbailable warrant for arrest was ordered to be issued.

facts.text: Bipat Gope filed petition under Art. 226 on April 29, 1958 against District Magistrate's order.

anchor.surface_text: On April 29, 1958, Bipat Gope moved a petition under Art. 226-against the order of the District Magistrate and the High Court directed on May 1, 1958, that Bipat Gope should appear on Monday following which was May 5, 1958

facts.text: Patna High Court directed Bipat Gope to appear on May 5, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On April 29, 1958, Bipat Gope moved a petition under Art. 226-against the order of the District Magistrate and the High Court directed on May 1, 1958, that Bipat Gope should appear on Monday following which was May 5, 1958, when the petition was to be taken up for preliminary hearing.

facts.text: On May 1, 1958, Bipat Gope appeared before District Magistrate and applied for opportunity to present case in High Court due to apprehension of police maltreatment.

anchor.surface_text: On May 1, 1958, Bipat Gope appeared in the Court of the District Magistrate, Patna and made an application stating that he had filed the above mentioned petition in the High Court and that he had to appear there on Monday and he prayed that he be allowed an opportunity to present his case to the High Court and to avoid. his maltreatment at the hands of the police of which he was apprehensive.

facts.text: Senior Deputy Collector, Patna ordered Bipat Gope into custody and sent to jail.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberorder on the record showing what the District Magistrate did but from the respondents petition in the High Court it appears that the application before District Magistrate was taken up by the Senior Deputy Collector Patna, who ordered Bipat Gope to be taken into custody and sent him to jail.

facts.text: Earlier petition of Bipat Gope in High Court withdrawn on May 2, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The earlier petition of Bipat Gope filed in the High Court was withdrawn on May 2, 1958.

facts.text: Patna High Court on May 5, 1958 allowed petition, ordered Bipat Gope released, holding release by DM unconditional so no rearrest.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court heard the petition filed by the respondent on May 5, 1958, and after some amendments were made the petition was allowed and Bipat Gope was ordered to be released from custody. The High Court held that the order of release by the District Magistrate of Patna above referred to was an order for, his unconditional release and therefore he companyld number be rearrested.

facts.text: State's application under Art. 134(1)(c) dismissed by High Court; appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: It is against that order that the State has companye to this Court by special leave, its application under Art. 134  1  c - having been dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: No return filed by the State to the rule nisi issued by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On the petition under Art,. 226 filed by the respondent, the High Court issued a, rule calling upon the appellant State to show cause why a writ of habeas companypus should number issue. It is unfortunate that numberreturn was filed by the State

facts.text: Dr. V. N. Sinha certified on February 21, 1958 that Bipat Gope suffering from disease, not improving, would improve if released.

anchor.surface_text: There are, on the record certificates by Dr. V. N. Sinha, F. R. C, S., Professor of Clinical Surgery at the Patna Medical College stating the disease Bipat Gope was suffering from and that he was riot improving under the treatment he was being given. It was also stated therein that he would improve if he was released This was on February 21, 1958.

facts.text: Civil Surgeon Patna enquired March 1, 1958 if Bipat Gope in danger of death; Dr. Sinha replied March 3 and March 5, 1958 that complications could be fatal but likely to improve if released.

anchor.surface_text: The Civil Surgeon of Patna on March, 1, 1958, again enquired from Dr. N. Sinha if the prisoner  Bipat Gope  was in danger of death from illness. Upon this on March 3, The companyplications of the disease i. e. of ventral hernia, peotic under and strees and strain syndrome sometime prove fatal. and on March 5, 1958, it was stated that he was in danger of death but was likely to improve if released.

facts.text: District Magistrate's order dated March 7, 1958: Allowed release in the circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the District Magistrate was -,Allowed release in the circumstances.

facts.text: Release from jail in Form No. 105 mentioning Rules 548, 549, 552 none scored out; sureties declared to surrender Bipat Gope by July 9, 1958 if required.

anchor.surface_text: in support reliance is placed on the release order of Bipat Gope which is in Form No. 105. That Form mentions Rules 548, 549 and 552 and the Rule which was number appropriate had to be scored out but numbere of these Rules was scored out. But at the bottom of the Form there is a declaration of two persons who started that they are willing to take. charge of Bipat Gope and bound themselves to surrender him at any time before the date of his expiry i. e. July 9, 1958 if required to- do so.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds it not clear under which rule Bipat Gope was released; no lawful authority shown for rearrest; detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: It has number been shown in this case that there was any lawful authority under which Bipat Gope was rearrested and in the absence of such lawful authority Bipat Gopes detention cannot be supported and is illegal.

holdings.text: Neither the order of the District Magistrate nor the Form 105 shows that Bipat Gope was released under R. 549 and not under any other Rule.

anchor.surface_text: The orders on the record do number make that clear. Neither the order of the District Magistrate number the Form 105 shows that Bipat Gope was released under R. 549 and number under any other Rule. The State has number cared to make it clear in any return made on an affidavit filed as to the Rule under which Bipat Gope was released and then it is number shown as to what lawful authority there was for his rearrest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: District Magistrate's order vague; Peshkar note mentions Rules 548 and 549 without specification; Form 105 lists multiple rules none scored out; no affidavit from State clarifying.

holdings.text: In the absence of a properly drawn up return accompanied by proper documents it is not possible to find out what exactly happened in regard to the rearrest of Bipat Gope and it is for that reason that the filing of a proper return is necessary and is insisted upon in most jurisdictions.

anchor.surface_text: On the petition under Art,. 226 filed by the respondent, the High Court issued a, rule calling upon the appellant State to show cause why a writ of habeas companypus should number issue. It is unfortunate that numberreturn was filed by the State and it is number clear from the record as to how exactly or under what authority Bipat Gope was taken into custody and under what authority the jailor was detaining him in jail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No return filed by State to rule nisi; unclear authority for custody and detention; proper return essential to ascertain facts in habeas corpus proceedings.

holdings.text: It is the same jurisprudence which has been adopted in this country on the basis of which the courts of this country exercise jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with Britain jurisprudence numbermember of.the executive can interfere with the liberty or property of a British subject except on the companydition that he can support the legality of his action before a Court of justice. And it is the tradition of British justice that Judges should number shrink from deciding such issues in the face of the execu- tive. It is the same jurisprudence which has been adopted in this companyntry

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Lord Atkin in Eshugbayi Eleko; executive interference with liberty requires legal justification supportable in court; principle adopted in India for court jurisdiction.

holdings.text: It has not been shown in this case that there was any lawful authority under which Bipat Gope was rearrested and in the absence of such lawful authority Bipat Gopes detention cannot be supported and is illegal.

anchor.surface_text: It has number been shown in this case that there was any lawful authority under which Bipat Gope was rearrested and in the absence of such lawful authority Bipat Gopes detention cannot be supported and is illegal. In the circumstances the remedy under Art.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No clarification via affidavit on release rule or rearrest authority; applies doctrine requiring executive to prove legality of detention.

precedents.cited_proposition: No member of the executive can interfere with the liberty or property of a subject except on the condition that he can support the legality of his action before a court of justice, and judges should not shrink from deciding such issues in the face of the executive.

outcome.relief_summary: Detention of Bipat Gope held illegal due to lack of lawful authority for rearrest; High Court order upheld implicitly
